comments_since_last_sample.body:
As a reminder, this subreddit [is for civil discussion.](/r/politics/wiki/index#wiki_be_civil)

In general, be courteous to others. Debate/discuss/argue the merits of ideas, don't attack people. Personal insults, shill or troll accusations, hate speech, any suggestion or support of harm, violence, or death, and other rule violations can result in a permanent ban. 

If you see comments in violation of our rules, please report them.

 For those who have questions regarding any media outlets being posted on this subreddit, please click [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/politics/wiki/approveddomainslist) to review our details as to our approved domains list and outlet criteria.

***


*I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Please [contact the moderators of this subreddit](/message/compose/?to=/r/politics) if you have any questions or concerns.*
So much for if you have nothing to hide you have nothing to fear.
How is that legal?
Hey, if steve bannon can ignore a subpoena, I say this faculty can ignore this bullshit.
This seems like something that wouldn't hold up in court given that a subpoena from a court is probably going to be a little higher than a private board's directive.

Desantis has also said faculty at state run universities have to fill out a survey on their beliefs. 

If I were a prof, I would lie like crazy on that form. 

https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.tampabay.com/news/florida-politics/2021/06/22/state-university-faculty-students-to-be-surveyed-on-beliefs/%3foutputType=amp

Is this legal? Also say in some imaginary world DeSantis committed a crime relating to these professors in some way. Would these people not be allowed to testify because UF considers it detrimental to the state to testify against its leader?
Just subpoena them.
Right wing attacks on the constitution will never stop.
Phew! For a minute there I thought we were heading into a Democratic Party lead dystopian nightmare where the government could tell people what to say. /s
Where is the usual eagle-crew that normal chants things about CeNsOrShIp?

Maybe it's my imagination, but I'm seeing the potential for an ever greater defiance against our laws.

First it was U.S. Congress.  I'm not sure what rationalizations are being offered, exactly, but I could see a rationalization of the U.S. Congress not being a legal body, and partisan, so it's ok to defy subpoenas.  "They shouldn't have subpoena power anyway." (nevermind that I suspect they would expect witnesses to testify when subpoenaed when they are in control).  Also freely lie to Congress while under oath.

Next is U.S. civil trials.  "There was and is no 'criminal' crime being committed, so there is no need to show up at trial." Also freely lie to the court while under oath.  After all, it's not a criminal trial and nothing criminal or major happened.

Finally, U.S. criminal trials against their (usually powerful) allies.  "We are teh LAW! Also it's all a witchunt anyway.  No need to testify, speak truthfully, or answer subpoenas."

Now this is an actual First Amendment violation.

A state actor, the University of Florida, is interfering with the free speech rights of its employees.

Ring wingers should take note. They constantly complain about First Amendment violations when private actors like social media companies act to limit speech. But the First Amendment only applies to government entites, like this state-sponsored university.
Ladies and gentlemen, the party of free speech.
Subpoena these expert witnesses. Let’s see university counsel defend their ludicrous position to the court.

One thing that’s been a little surprising, I guess not that surprising, is just how corrupt many of our institutions of higher learning seem to be. I would think faculty would be quicker to organize mass strikes and walkouts.
I went to UF for 2 years and loved the school- 90% of the students & professors I met were kind and surprisingly liberal. The higher ups may not be… lol
NYU should offer those faculty a position and $5,000 bonus.
Nothing says “good faith government” like barring people from speaking about the effects of policy…

I’m not a lawyer, but I’m under the impression that if this were a criminal case (which honestly I think it should be, since depriving people of their voting rights under color of law facially meets the elements of multiple criminal laws), then what UF is doing would itself be criminal obstruction.

It may not be criminal here, but I feel that the same moral principles apply - so fuck them.
**Freedom of speech**, I mean, what is it *really?*
Yeah that ain't legal
They should testify and then call in the fed when they get fired, make DeSantis sweat.
For anyone more well versed than I am; This UF rule cannot supersede a court's subpoena, can it?
So what are they hiding

I don't understand how the swamp people still support this guy. He's fighting against government mandates by enacting a government mandate.  I mean f'cking hell, are they blind to what this fraud is doing?
Really solidifies their values....a fantastic lessons to teach Young adults about how morals and truthfulness don't line your pockets full of cash.
Question : can they go to testify as a private citizen as in “ I’m here as a private citizen to testify not representing U F “

Florida Republicans: I love America. I love the Constitution. 

Also Republicans: but not the part that disagrees with me or might make me look bad.
And we have a tenure system … why again?
I have no love for the University of Florida, but it’s not the student’s fault.   This would disproportionately hurt students more than the university, especially in the near term.
The university is basically acting as a political entity, and demanding a specific political stance from employees?
This speed at which this country is losing democracy is accelerating day by day
Later Gators.  Y'all just go fuck youselves.
Fuck Florida.
Academic freedom, 1st Amendment rights; this is a bullshit attack on the faculty.
This is a blatant violation of the First Amendment.  They should testify and then sue UF for violating their constitutional rights if there is any blow back.
Good luck enforcing that one.

tldr; UF has some big election researchers, UF is a state school, and in Florida state schools are *directly* linked to the state gov, so they blocked them from testifying

edit: using my top level comment to share that FPL (largest florida utility) has basically [seized control of it's own state regulatory board](https://www.sun-sentinel.com/opinion/editorials/fl-op-edit-florida-power-light-raising-rates-20211029-eulqrric35fj5jskosdbg5jype-story.html)
